results.title: Gas pressure and molecular collisions
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Educational Services and Chemistry Educational Materials Study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Explores the relationship between gaseous pressure and molecular collisions. Studies the effects of varying the number of molecules per unit of volume and of varying the temperature. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Gas from Gippsland
results.creator_credit: Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: Describes the construction of the Brown Coal Gasification Plant at Morwell in Victoria’s Latrobe Valley. The Plant is designed to use the Lurgi High Pressure Gasification process and will be immediately capable of delivering 15 million cubic feet daily. Shows the laying of the 103 mile gas pipe-line to Melbourne and the official opening of the Plant by HRH the Duke of Edinburgh in December 1956.

results.title: Gas for home and industry
results.brief_description: Fuel gas as a source of energy in modern society. Compares the use of gas at the turn of the century with its present-day use for cooking, water heating, space heating and refrigeration. Production processes for three types of manufactured gas are described; coke oven gas, carburetted water gas and oil gas. Research work on improved methods of gas production is illustrated including the method based on the catalyst cracking process.

results.title: Gary Cooper - American Life, American Legend
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood narrates this documentary on popular American actor Gary Cooper (1901-61), who enjoyed great fame and prosperity in Hollywood, particularly during the 1930s, 40s and 50s. Coop, as he is affectionately called, was the everyman of Hollywood cinema, often assuming roles as the romantic lead, upstanding citizen and cowboy, ironing out trouble and restoring peace to lawless frontier towns. Coop’s protagonists, stern and moral men, were often capable of displaying a naive quality and innocence when it came to romance. In the title role of “Mr Deeds goes to town” (Capra, 1936) Cooper played a moralistic citizen who inherits great wealth and distinguishes himself by assisting the underprivileged masses; the actor soon after became the personification of the model American male - strong, idealistic, upstanding, heterosexual and somewhat overwhelmed when in love. Other famous roles include “Meet John Doe”, “High noon”, “The Fountainhead”, “Love in the afternoon”, “For whom the bell tolls” and “Sergeant York”. This documentary chronologically follows Cooper’s career without really discussing the man behind the myth, instead presenting extensive clips from the actor’s many films and exploring his public persona. Briefly touches on Cooper’s role in the investigation by the House of the Un-American Activities, as a friendly witness, and his affair with actress Patricia Neal.

results.title: Gary's story
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, AFTRS and Richard Michalak
results.brief_description: A comical drama about a young man’s search for sexual filfilment. Gary (John Howard) awkwardly obsesses over finding a girlfriend. He heads off to Sydney for a new job with many expectations, leaving his flatmate and those ‘desperate vibes’ behind. Unable to assert himself, Gary sabotages his dreams of sexual fulfillment by allowing a neurotic acquaintance (Joyce) from his desperate past to infiltrate and dominate his life. The director Richard Michalak offers a number of humorous asides playfully referencing the film-making process. When his dreams are shattered, Gary tries to sort out the mess and promptly delivers a script with the demand “this is my story and I want an up ending”. Cast includes John Howard, Katrina Foster, Kate Fitzpatrick and Patrick Ward.

results.title: Gary
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, David Haythornthwaite and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
After a period of abrasive conflict Gary’s parents have separated. The effect of this is shown on the whole family, but Gary is so deeply affected, that his insecurities produce a stomach ulcer. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Garry Greenwood: leather worker
results.creator_credit: Australia Council and Dinah Van Dugteren
results.brief_description: Garry Greenwood works at shaping leather into sculptural forms by hammering it over a stone. He also runs a gallery at his mill in Deloraine, Tasmania, and gathers most of his inspiration from nature. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Garrison at Dhurringile: officers p.o.w. camp Tatura
results.brief_description: Footage of Dhurringile, the internment camp and military hospital, Tatura during or possibly just after the second world war. Tatura housed refugees from Europe and South East Asia (classified as enemy aliens) and was also a P.O.W. camp, housing German officers and batmen from the merchant ship Kormoran which sank HMAS Sydney in 1941. This film deals with an unknown parade outside the camp (possibly ANZAC) populated by soldiers from both world wars.

results.title: Garin Nugroho: my family, my film and my nation
results.creator_credit: S E T Film Workshop and Garin Nugroho
results.brief_description: Garin Nugroho narrates this collage of his own documentaries and films. He talks about the films and how he associates them with his personal life. There are clips from his feature ‘Letter for an Angel’ and documentaries ‘Water and Romi’ and ‘Tale of a Mousedeer’ which inspired the feature ‘Leaf on a Pillow’. Nugroho also articulates his concerns for the failing condition of his country. In Bahasa Indonesia with English subtitles.
